Bayesian statistics is the fortune teller statistic.  If it turns out that this video is correct, people will make lots of videos and papers saying HAH! it was right!  But if this completely wrong and we are part of one of the small groups, people will make lots of papers and videos saying that Bayesian statistics was right!  Why?  Because if we first approach the same problem while looking at humanity as a whole group rather than as an individual of the species.  Bayesian statistics say that it is more likely that our "group" or species is part of the larger number of groups with less population.  So you draw precisely the opposite conclusion with the same data point using the same logical reasoning and be right both ways.  This makes it completely useless to focus on searching for one type of planet and instead means we should continue what we are doing, searching for as many as we can find until we get more points of data.

Seems that assuming you're part of the biggest group is different to assuming your group is the biggest. If you don't know your blood type it would be safer to assume it's A+/O+ as a majority of people have that characteristic, but since minority blood type groups outnumber the majority groups six to two (i.e., there are more minority classifications albeit with fewer people in each) it wouldn't be safer to know you're A- and assume that A- is the biggest group. Statistically there are two separate questions here: "What's the probably subject N belongs to group X?" (population size known but characteristic unknown) vs "What's the probability group X will be among the most highly populated groups?" (characteristic known but population size unknown). We can't answer the second question without knowing population sizes/ranges from other data points.

this is based on flawed logic.

As individuals we are more likely to be part of a large group, ok, but the group we're discussing isn't individual humans, its species. So our species is likely to be part of a larger group of species that lives in worlds like ours, but our species population has no bearing on anything else. That we have 7 billion individual humans has no bearing on us being 1 specie. So how can we infer other species will have lower populations simply because we have a higher population?

This argument suggests that our population size is a characteristic that would likely fall in a large group of simular species with simular population densities, so that most other species will have simular population sizes. Mixing statistics related to individual humans with statistics related to individual species is completely wrong-headed.

When we talk about what percent of planets are simular to ours, that's a different question, because our sun is actually quantifiably fairly rare. The star the planet orbits is the biggest factor of what conditions you could expect. Our sun is bigger and younger than most stars, and most stars are part of binary systems. Stars larger than ours are relatively rare, but very short lived. In a billion years our sun will start to grow into a red giant, and kill all life on earth, yet it took 4.5 billion years for Earth to evolve us. If our sun had been any bigger, our planet wouldn't have had enough time to evolve multicellular life. If our world's evolutionary rate is indicative of any sort of average, any star bigger than ours would burn out too quick to evolve complex life like us. So, likely, we're close to the upper limit of star size (which is inversely related to lifespan rather dramatically), for life to evolve on.

So yes, by that logic, most life would evolve on systems with red dwarfs binaries, because that's a lot more common.

But there is a fair amount of evidence that suggests that life on land is a lot rarer than life in water. Life originates in water, and then has to evolve to go on land. This must be incredibly hard, based on the various factors that make life possible on land here on Earth. Here's some things we think we know =

1) Red stars tend to be older, because they last longer and have a much wider age distribution, and contain less heavy elements. Fewer heavy elements would mean gas giants instead of rocky worlds, and rocky worlds with smaller metal cores which would lead to an absence of van allen radiation belts. Life on land would be very difficult if our planet had no shield against radiation, though water based life would still be ok. The van allan radiation belts are only possible because our planet has a spinning metal core, that would only be possible in younger stars formed from supernova dust like ours.

2) Also red dwarf stars are very variable in radiation output (by as much as 40%). Life in water would survive that, because water can store heat and remain liquid under ice sheets (though how would it retain enough oxygen or recieve enough sunlight?) and remain liquid near the poles if rest of planet dries up, but life on land would be much harder.

3) Red dwarves have smaller goldilocks zones, and a tendency for planets in that goldilocks zones to be tidally locked, which is highy disadvantagous for life as only a small ring of a planet's surface would be at the right temperture for liquid water and constant super fast wind due to temperature differences would kill any organisms that tried to live on land.

4) Binary systems are also highly problematic for life on land, as the amount of energy a world recieves would vary wildly as it orbits multiple stars, since orbits around the center of mass of two stars would place any planet dangerously close to one or the other star at any given point in its orbit, and when one star eclipses the other, you'd get sudden super-winters. In the water, you might be ok, but on land, you would be toast or frozen.

5) Also, it is likely that the amount of atmosphere and water a planet has is closely tied to its size. Super-earth sized planets are likely completely covered by water, and smaller than earth sized planets probably all end up like mars with little atmosphere at all. Every planet gradually loses water and air to space which gets replenished to maintain an equilibrium. Bigger the world, the more water and air it can hold on to. Earth is just the right size, small so it doesn't have enough water to cover the highest 30% of it's surface, but big enough to hold onto an atmosphere thick enough that life can breathe on land. That ideal size is probably a fairly narrow range.

For these reasons, aquatic life is probably much much more common in the universe than land based organisms. But even if intelligent life did evolve on a world that can't support life on land, how would it develop technology? Aquatic intelligences, like say dolphins, likely never evolve hands... and if they did, without fire, how would they progress past stone age technology? I won't say technologically advanced aquatic intelligent life is impossible, but it would surely be much much harder. Think about how challenging it would be to build a rocket that could leave your home planet from underwater, where would you even begin?

Is it safe to treat humans as "individuals," though? Or should we be considering Earth itself as an individual?

If you're going to tie the size of the individual with the size of a planet, then the most important factor is going to be the size of the planet. Planets do not grow or shrink with population size, so using population size to infer planet size is not valid. Rather, it is the other way around: You need to estimate the average size of inhabited planets first, then infer the size of the individual afterwards.

Fergus also makes a major misstep with "What if people who lived several centuries ago did a calculation on how many births there would be?"

His response is: "But those first 5% of people who ever lived represent the 5% of the time we expect to be wrong."

Where does he get 5% from? Comparing one slice of time to another slice of time? That's invalid - out of all of the inhabited planets in the universe, they can be at any stage of population growth. There is no reason to think that our current population is typical - and indeed, it is very atypical if compared to the rest of our history. Using an atypical point in population growth to determine what you think the typical population of a planet is seems rather reckless.

If he's attempting to compare everybody who ever lived with the current population, then he's terribly wrong as well. Current estimates of the number of people who have ever lived is on the order of 100 billion. The current population is the "5%," not the other way around, if you choose to measure it in that way. Although - why you would measure it that way? The total number of people who have ever lived seems irrelevant to the issue at hand.

There is no reason to assume that our population in the present day is a typical population.

And it's not as if we have zero data. So far, the candidates of potentially habitable planets we've discovered are largely "superearths" - planets larger than Earth. Which is contrary to the predictions of this video. Of course, the sample is likely biased due to technological limitations (smaller planets are more difficult to detect than large ones), but it may be an indicator that we're a bit off the mark on this prediction.

Interesting thought experiment, although nothing but conjecture. If you start to use proven facts as a basis to extrapolate the most likely places to find alien life instead of pure statistics, the whole picture changes. The one environment that we have prove of that life can develop are the conditions we find with our own planet. That's it. There is not one shred of additional data, but this one bit of data we do have is irrefutably proven to be correct. Based on this alone, the highest probability of finding life should be with planets that offer similar conditions to Earth. Of course this doesn't rule out the possibility of life in other conditions, in theory even silicon-based life is a possibility, but based on the data we have, looking for life on Earth-like planets should be our best bet.

The other problem I have with this thought experiment is that it is solely based on the assumption that we are part of the biggest group, simply because statistics says it is the most likely. Again, statistics tells us that we are most likely part of the biggest group based on pure theory, not on any available data of actually existing life. And for this, one data point is simply insufficient for anything else but a nifty thought experiment. We might statistically be less likely to be a part of a small group, but there is simply no way of determining this with just one data point. An insanely dedicated fan of AFC Wimbledon (and I'm sure you made John Green's day with this reference) who is otherwise for whatever reason oblivious to other soccer teams might just as well think that he is part of the biggest, most dedicated group of football fans there is. He simply has to, because he doesn't know better. And the same goes for us when we assume to be part of the biggest statistical group, simply because is is the statistically most likely.

I think it comes down to this: If you want to prove that live can arise in environments different to Earth's, you will likely succeed by looking at places other than Earth-like planets. (Well, duh!) If you want to prove that ANY alien life exists, however, your safest bet (and the most economical method considering our limited resources for this search) is to start at places where the data we have irrefutably suggest that life can exist in the first place.

It's a nice thought experiment, though, and a beautiful way to visualize the concept of statistical probability.
